results.title: True and fake Monkey Kings = Zhen Jia Mei Hou Wang
results.creator_credit: Fang Ying, Li Bangjin, Shi Jie and Pearl River Film Studio
results.brief_description:
The group are set upon by the Six-Eared Monkey, who uses his magic to possess three forest animals, transforming them into the exact duplicates of each of our heroes. Though he is initially defeated, he manages to escape from the animals’ dead bodies and retreats to the heavens in order to safely plot his comeback.
The band continue their journey into the land of Xiliang, the kingdom of women. The leader of our heroes, Monk Tripytaka (a.k.a. Xuanzang), is given an audience with the queen of Xiliang, who is rapt with sweet meloncholy, as she waits for her true love to grace the illustrious court. Yet it turns out she has been waiting a little too long to be picky about her men, and she falls instantly in love with the graceful young monk.
After she invites them all to rest for a while in her kingdom, the queen speaks with Xuanzang, explaining that she has been a maid for 30 years. When she propositions him and asks his hand in marriage Wukong intervenes and accepts on Xuanzang’s behalf, thus buying them some time to devise a plan of escape. Meanwhile, the Six-Eared Monkey listens in on their plan and devises a counter strategy to harrass them.
Wukong turns himself into a copy of Xuangzhao and meets with the queen, who calls in her guards when she realises the hoax. By this time Xuanzang and the others have escaped. The devil disguised as Wukong kills all these enemies, despite Xuanzang’s order to show them mercy. The real Wukong is then reprimanded and sent back to his cave. This is the second time Wukong has been expelled.
The fake king comes and steal sthe border pass then goes off to finish the king, who is conversing with Guanyin. Monkey returns to his cave at Flower Fruit Mountain to battle the evil monkey. They fight and he burns the pass. Bodhisattva (a.k.a. Guanyin) intervenes, revealing a vase that contains all the waters of the ocean. However her vase fails to distinguish the real from the false. So she sends them both to the Jade Emperor to determine the truth. He then refers them on to the Buddha, who finally uncovers the fake monkey and sucks him into his heart.

Cultural History of the Film:

There are a variety of amazing acrobatic feats, which include balancing swords and throwing them behind the back into the scabbard.

results.title: Bayi Gardiya (Singing Desert)
results.credit_line:
Creative technology studio: Nakatomi
Performed by Christian Thompson
Composed by Christian Thompson and Mark Mitchell
Sound production by Mark Mitchell at Electric Dreams Studio
With special thanks to Rachael Sheridan, Jeanette Little and Leyla Varela
results.material_description: 360 degree video, VR system, headphones, sand and AIATSIS map of Indigenous Australia
results.brief_description:
Bayi Gardiya (Singing Desert) is an immersive, 360 degree moving image and sound experience.

The environment within Bayi Gardiya situates a visitor in the creek bed of The Sixth Mile, Barcaline, western Queensland. The imagery and sound within transforms from morning to midday and then to twilight and night. These transitions also shift through seasonal change to represent and also comment on the impacts of Global Warming on the fragile, semi-desert Hinterland and country represented in the work.

results.title: Access Video 1973-1982
results.creator_credit: Helen Eisler and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
The results of a reserach project funded by the Australian Film Commission and the Commonwealth Employment Programme this title presents highlights of programmes of historical importance, demonstrating the growth and maturing of independent video which in turn reflects the development of community and political activity during the seventies.

During this decade 12 access video centres were established. This title shows highlights of proigrammes made by various centres.

results.title: Davey Jones Locker
results.description: Creating an alternative history by imagining that the children of African slaves thrown overboard during the Middle Passage built a technologically advanced underwater civilization beneath the Atlantic Ocean, Detroit’s Drexciya were one of the key Afrofuturist duos of the 1990s. Their mythology and worldbuilding inspired many artsts, musicians and filmmakers - and their hard hitting electro and techno beats spread this mythology on the dancefloor.
description_for_label: Creating an alternative history by imagining that the children of African slaves thrown overboard during the Middle Passage built a technologically advanced underwater civilization beneath the Atlantic Ocean, Detroit’s Drexciya were one of the key Afrofuturist duos of the 1990s. Their mythology and worldbuilding inspired many artsts, musicians and filmmakers - and their hard hitting electro and techno beats spread this mythology on the dancefloor.

results.title: Godzilla in gaming
results.material_description: Screen recordings of Snipe and Wib, Friday Night Arcade and MoviEVo's YouTube channels
results.brief_description: In the early 1980s, Godzilla stomped his way onto screens through retro gaming. Godzilla (C64) (1983) first gave players a pixelated monster’s view, smashing through cities. Then came Fierce Dragon Godzilla: Metropolis Destruction (1985), a Japan-only release where Godzilla unleashed havoc on urban landscapes. The Movie Monster Game (1986) let players choose from multiple kaiju, including Godzilla, to demolish cityscapes. In Godzilla vs. 3 Giant Monsters (1984), Godzilla took on three classic kaiju in turn-based battles, bringing strategic clashes to the gaming world. Each game added to the legend, expanding the King of the Monsters’ digital footprint.

results.title: Remixing Godzilla
results.material_description: Screen recordings of @gentlebl0ke (Moo Deng and Pesto), @phthartic5 (Roar), @ideatimes (Crab legs), @beeragon (Barbie), @jaydent.26 (Fashion)
results.brief_description: Seventy years ago, when the original Godzilla film was released no one had any idea of the global impact this monster would have. As the number of films in the Godzilla franchise has increased over the decades so has the number of fans and their devotion to the King of the Monsters. These clips are an example of the ways Godzilla is celebrated and re-invented by the fans - from a comparison of monster roars from across the franchise, a fashion call out for the Godzilla themed shoes worn by the team which won the first Oscar for a Godzilla film, and a fan mash up of Godzilla and Barbie.
results.description: Seventy years ago, when the original Godzilla film was released no one had any idea of the global impact this monster would have. As the number of films in the Godzilla franchise has increased over the decades so has the number of fans and their devotion to the King of the Monsters. These clips are an example of the ways Godzilla is celebrated and re-invented by the fans - from a comparison of monster roars from across the franchise, a fashion call out for the Godzilla-themed shoes worn by the cast of Godzilla Minus One, and a fan mash-up of Godzilla and Barbie.

results.title: Play It Again I: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again I project aimed to create a playable history of Australasian video games for industry, community and research purposes, by building on existing research into the history of Beam Software and their games from the 1980s.

This collection comprises physical games donated to ACMI for the project, audio captures and game emulation files – some created at ACMI as part of the project research and some harvested from external web repositories.

The multi-faceted project brought multidisciplinary expertise to bear on the areas of collections, preservation, accessibility, fan knowledge, and the telling of histories about Australia’s digital game history.

The project was undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Flinders University, University of Melbourne, The New Zealand Film Archive, Berlin Computerspiele Museum, and the Research Trust of Victoria University of Wellington. It was funded via the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Projects scheme, which funds collaborative projects between University researchers and Partner Organisations.

The project was completed in 2015.

production_dates.notes: Games in this Collection date from the 1980s. The ARC research project "Play It Again" (I) was completed in 2015

results.title: Emulation of Aussie Games for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Aussie Games was made in response to the success of Epyx’s Californian Games (1987) and the popularity of the movie Crocodile Dundee (1986) in the United States.

A compendium of different games, it includes a boomerang throw, a bellywack competition, an Aussie Rules football punting game, a dry boat race and the infamous skeet shoot. In the skeet shoot game, you have to hit an empty beer can thrown from a moving ute. Success results in the dog, who is riding shotgun in the ute, chundering! “Aussie Games” offered a very tongue in cheek survey of Australian sporting prowess. The games were developed individually by differing Beam staff with Gregg Barnett as the producer. Russel Comte’s graphics for Aussie Games are most humerous.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/aussie-games/

Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Mindscape Inc for Commodore 64, published in 1989 by Beam Software

results.title: The Muncher for ZX Spectrum 128
results.creator_credit: Beam Software, Zero Wait, Gremlin Graphics Software and Rob Howard
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, badge and manual in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: The Muncher [computer game]. The Muncher is a single player side scrolling action game. Players control a rampaging monster destroying buildings by climbing on them, breathing fire and jumping on people and cars while attempting to avoid getting shot at by people with guns. The game ends when the monster’s health has been depleted by being attacked.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Beam Software, Zero Wait, Gremlin Graphics Software and Rob Howard
results.description: The Muncher [computer game]. The Muncher is a single player side scrolling action game. The game ends when the monster’s health has been depleted by being attacked.

Players control a rampaging monster destroying buildings by climbing on them, breathing fire and jumping on people and cars while attempting to avoid getting shot at by people with guns. The game ends when the monster’s health has been depleted by being attacked.
